body: Ooops.  Sorry for forgetting to squash first.  Will do as part of any merge, of course.
Aaaand I didn't see GEODE-4858 / #1822, which would conflict and is probably preferable to just pressing those methods down.  I'll close this for now and update after that's resolved.
There are no output/formatting changes resulting from this.
@smgoller This change is to archive UITest results.

I merged develop into the branch to ensure that recent cluster config changes where sync'd up.
Precheckin was green prior to the merge.
Closed because develop diverged too far from this branch to reasonably sync-up. New PR was opened.
Whoops, I broke it -- no need to review until I fix what I broke.

I meant to put this in the commit message, but it must've gotten lost when I rebased:

Changes include:
* Those getters that return a `List` have been renamed to indicate a plural.
* Much of the "massaging" has been documented in the `bindings.xjb` file.  Comments document what other adjustments have been made, at time of writing.
* A more-restrictive xsd has been included in `configurationService.xsd` that removes deprecated items that should not be supported by this new feature.
* Configuration classes have been generated as `Serializable`, as this will be required when the creation commands et al pass configuration objects to instantiate the services they support.

I have included the `xjc` tasks I used to generate these objects in their respective `gradle` files, as well as the bindings file each task would produce.  These could have future value if this process is repeated, but I could also see the value in keeping our build files from becoming cluttered.

This PR does _not_ update or adjust any of the configuration objects in `geode-connectors` or `geode-lucene`.  Those can be addressed in another ticket.

@jhuynh1 this PR was a follow-up to these two commits in https://github.com/apache/geode/pull/1828:
* GEODE-1279: Rename HARegionQueueSizeRegressionTest
* GEODE-5020: Move HARegionQueue system properties to SystemPropertyHelper

Feel free to make any changes including category changes! Thanks.
Made some small updates to the tests. I'll squash and reword before merging.

Actually, with the more-recent changes to `spotless`, this would fail the build after being merged in.  (There is an unused import in `DistributedSystemIdDUnitTest.java` after merging.)  Sorry to shift the goal posts on you.

But, since it looks like it should merge cleanly, and since it's been over a month with this PR open already, I'll take care of it.
After a PR is already open, please merge rather than rebasing and forcing a push.  When you do, we lose chronology and any context of what we have or haven't already reviewed.
Reviewing now, but may take some time since there are a lot of changes.

Surprisingly, a dunit failure occurred in the following:
```
ClearTXLockingDUnitTest. testPutWithClearDifferentVM
DataSerializerPropagationDUnitTest. testDataSerializersEventIdVerificationClientsAndServers
```

Both extend the unreliable `JUnit4DistributedTestCase`.  I'm rerunning them now.
Rerun was green.  We should refactor these `JUnit4DistributedTestCase` soon...
Precheckin was green.  Meant to post that before merging.
My previous precheckin failed to launch the DUnits.  While I expect no problem, currently waiting for that green.
There we go.  Green across the board.  Such a surprise.
precheckin is green for this change too

Also:
* Moved getRegionTTLExpiryTask and getRegionIdleExpiryTask to InternalRegion
* Extracted ExpirationDetector because RemoteTransactionDUnitTest uses it
thanks @jinmeiliao I have added a test.

Precheckin green, excepting a `flakyTest` failure in `LauncherLifecycleCommandsDUnitTest. testVersionTitleForStartServerAndLocator`.  Rerunning to confirm that this didn't somehow make that failure deterministic.

Precheckin green, excepting a `flakyTest` failure in `ConcurrentSerialGatewaySenderOperationsDUnitTest. testRestartSerialGatewaySendersWhilePutting`. Rerunning now to make sure this didn't somehow make that failure deterministic.

Two things:

* Though beyond the scope of this ticket, I think the addition of an explicit "This hasn't persisted" in the event of error would be a good addition to the recent changes surrounding the `SingleGfshCommand`.
* To limit scope, I don't actually pass the `GatewayReceiver` configuration object to the members, but dissect it for consumption by the existing framework.  I could go either way on whether or not the configuration object itself should be the core of the function arguments.
Precheckin green excepting a flaky test failure in `ConcurrentSerialGatewaySenderOperationsDUnitTest`.  Rerunning now, just to be sure.

I think Dan has a good point.  It is a bit confusing to have the old GemFire numbers and new Geode numbers without "GFE" and "GEODE" in the method names.  I think I'm going to yank this PR.  I've created a different ticket to improve our help for developers in catching naming mistakes.

I've added `GEODE-5185` to the head of this PR, since they both touch the same command.

The commit message should probably prioritize that ticket rather than the refactor, to something like
```
GEODE-5185: Correct backwards-compatibility violation in 'create gateway-receiver' command.
* Also refactored command per GEODE-4858 and GEODE-5010 to use the SingleGfshCommand and ResultModel classes, respectively.
```

I've run a precheckin based off (a merge-resolved copy of) this PR.  As per the previous attempt, the `SessionReplicationIntegrationJUnitTest` blows up badly.

Originally, the error appeared to be [JOG4J2-2152](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LOG4J2-2152).  In the discussion of the related ticket [LOG4J2-2266](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LOG4J2-2266), it looks like the true error stems from how Log4j2 interacts with the class loader, which in turn causes tests run with the `PerTestClassLoaderRunner` to fail.

I've opened [GEODE-5189](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GEODE-5189) to address the test refactoring.  Updating Log4j will be blocked until this can be addressed.

As an aside, it may be worth noting in `dependency-versions.properties` that both Jetty and Tomcat have hard-coded versions defined in some respective tests.  I'm not familiar with those tests in particular, just something I noticed.  It might be worth having, though...

```

diff --git a/gradle/dependency-versions.properties b/gradle/dependency-versions.properties
index bf4876c..42077bb 100644
--- a/gradle/dependency-versions.properties
+++ b/gradle/dependency-versions.properties
@@ -55,6 +55,8 @@ javax.resource-api.version = 1.7
 javax.servlet-api.version = 3.1.0
 javax.transaction-api.version = 1.2
 jedis.version = 2.9.0
+# The jetty version is also hard-coded in geode-assembly:test
+# at o.a.g.sessions.tests.GenericAppServerInstall.java
 jetty.version = 9.4.8.v20171121
 jgroups.version = 3.6.14.Final
 jmock.version = 2.8.2
@@ -96,6 +98,8 @@ springfox.version=2.8.0
 stephenc-findbugs.version = 1.3.9-1
 system-rules.version = 1.17.1
 tempus-fugit.version = 1.1
+# Multiple versions of tomcat are hard-coded in geode-assembly:test
+# at o.a.g.session.tests.TomcatInstall
 tomcat6.version = 6.0.37
 tomcat7.version = 7.0.73
 tomcat8.version = 8.5.9
```
@sboorlagadda Thanks for the review. Can you take another look at this PR?  I think I addressed all of your requested changes.
Message sent!  I'll give it another day, to hopefully make sure everyone has the chance to see the email.

@PurelyApplied & @kirklund Thanks for your review.

Precheckin is green. I would like to get this merged if I get one more

@upthewaterspout I agree with you.  This whole "holder" idea needs to be rethought and rewritten.  Also, the servers are sending the same instantiators and dataserializers on, I think, every handshake.  I don't think they need to do that on secondary connections.
It looks like #1938  should fix the outstanding issues.  I'll go ahead and merge the new HEAD of `develop` with this and rerun precheckin.

Oops, I messed up my branches and accidentally pushed the restoration of the build files.

Considering the drift between this and the extant iteration, I think I'll just close this PR for now and open a new one if it comes to that.
i have made all your required changes - please review it and add your comments
@kirklund @pdxrunner @nabarunnag I am tagging some tests that you might be interested in. Please let me know if the categorizations are inappropriate.

The updated precheckin run for [my branch of this work](https://github.com/PurelyApplied/geode/tree/geode-5001) came back green.  I don't know if you want to incorporate that into this PR or if I should open my own, but there it is.

Go ahead and create a new PR based on your changes. 

Anthony

@kirklund @pdxrunner All your great feedback should be addressed now and I categorized some more tests. Please take another look.

I think the remaining tests are better categorized by someone who is more intimately familiar with the specific components.

Commands that have been converted to use `ResultModel.createMemberStatusResult` will now display results with 3 columns (Member, Status and Message) instead of just Member and Status. For example:
```
Member   | Status  | Message
------------------------------------------
server-1 | OK      | Everything worked
server-2 | IGNORED | Region already exists
server-3 | ERROR   | Something is broken
```
'Legacy' commands will continue to show the old table. I don't think there's any point in having this PR make the output be consistent for both old and new as we're already sweeping through the commands making all the other changes right now.
Some instability in my precheckin made the DUni task dead on the vine.  Rerunning now.
@PurelyApplied good catch on that `REGION_NAME` comment. I'll remove it, since it doesn't seem to be hidden and it's both internal and pretty thoroughly baked in.
It's also a little bizarre that the full region name is not marked with the same "test only" comment.

The last commit removes the additional test hook. There is a small difference here in that the old one was checking a locally cached copy, but as a DUnit test of queries it shouldn't be that close to details of PDX that are that small.

EDIT: on second look, I thin\k there may not be a difference.
The precheckin had hung and timed out, so I've restarted it.
precheckin is good - I'll merge this
